docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Jay DeLaney of Morristownwould like his town to be the first in the state to offer health benefits to the domestic partners of municipal employees, gay or straight, married or unmarried. Last week Mr. DeLaney proposed extending the coverage now offered to married employees to unmarried employees willing to file a public declaration that they are cohabiting on a permanent basis with another person. If the union is dissolved, a cooling-off period would be required before the benefits could be offered to another domestic partner.

headline.main: Morristown Mayor Proposes Domestic Partners Coverage

docs.abstract: Morristown, NJ, Mayor Jay DeLaney says he will seek to have his town become first in state to offer health benefits to domestic partners of municipal employees, gay or straight, married or unmarried (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: FLUSH from their joint success in landing the New England Patriots, Gov. John G. Rowland and the Democrats who control both houses of the General Assembly were tripping over themselves last week with promises to work together during this year's legislative session. At the same time, however, they have announced conflicting priorities that could mean tense months ahead. Governor Rowland and his fellow Republicans in the legislature have stressed their desire to put a brake on, or even pare, state spending, while Democrats said they hoped to take advantage of the booming economy to make progress on education and other issues that took a back seat as the state struggled out of the recent recession.

headline.main: There's Money to Spend But Priorities Differ

docs.abstract: Connecticut Gov John Rowland and Democrats who control General Assembly have pledged to work together during 1999 legislative session but conflicting priorities portend tense months ahead; Rowland and Republicans have stressed desire to reduce or halt state spending, while Democrats wish to take advantage of booming economy to make progress on major issues that took back seat while state struggled out of recession; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: CAROL LEVINE has been caring for her husband, Howard, at home since 1990, when their car skidded on an icy highway in upstate New York and crashed into a guardrail, leaving him with a traumatic brain injury. While Mr. Levine, 71, is mentally alert, uses a wheelchair, and cannot feed himself or turn the pages of a magazine. He seldom leaves the couple's Manhattan apartment.

headline.main: Personal Business; Some Credit For Those Who Must Give Care

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton wins some praise for his proposals to provide tax credit of $1,000 a year for people who need long-term home health care and to offer Federal employees and retirees long-term care insurance at negotiated group rates; others would prefer to have Government subsidize long-term care insurance or improve coverage of home health services under Medicare; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A TENSE exchange last week between two liberal members of the National Bipartisan Commission on the Future of Medicare moved the group toward a dramatic agreement. The members agreed to develop a plan to radically revamp Medicare by giving its beneficiaries a fixed sum of money to buy private or public insurance. In short, the use of vouchers -- something liberals have shunned in education -- might be good for Medicare. Bruce C. Vladeck, a former administrator of Medicare, who is a staunch defender of the basic fee-for-service plan, began the debate by proposing that Medicare officials get stronger powers to restrict some medical practices, to negotiate fees and to favor participation by some physicians over others. A dissenting member, Stuart H. Altman, a Brandeis University professor, argued that Mr. Vladeck's proposals might result in excessive Governmental control. He could support them only if Medicare moved to a system of competing public and private health plans that would give the beneficiaries attractive ways to opt out of the traditional Government program. .

headline.main: The Nation: Fixing Medicare; Light at a Tunnel's End

docs.abstract: National Bipartisan Commission on Future of Medicare has agreed to develop plan to radically revamp Medicare by giving its beneficiaries fixed sum of money to buy private or public insurance; but Democrats are unlikely to approve any final voucher plan that lacks sufficient revenue for drugs and other essentials and fails to cover low-income families; they want to raise taxes to do that; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the first roll call of the 222d session of the New York State Legislature, the clerk had to say Thomas K. Duane's name three times before he responded, ''Here.'' Mr. Duane, the first openly gay member elected to the conservative, clubby fraternity that is the State Senate, had his back to the podium. His leather chair sat empty on the Democratic side of the gilded chamber. He was across the aisle, shaking hands with Republicans, introducing himself to the powerful majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, in one breath, and in the next, urging him to reconsider his denial of domestic-partner benefits to employees of the upper house.

headline.main: In Albany, Openly Gay State Senator Tests Unfamiliar, Conservative Turf

docs.abstract: Thomas K Duane, first openly gay member of New York State Senate, tests out unfamiliar conservative waters in Albany; photo; Republican leader Joseph Bruno offers 'hearty welcome' to Manhattan Democrat; Duane, wary of being one-note politician, plans to lobby on campaign finance reform and other issues, as well as being live example of gay person with HIV (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Jim McGreevey is running again. Six years after he was first elected Mayor of this sprawling township in central New Jersey, Mr. McGreevey is running for re-election. So far, no opponents have openly declared that they will challenge him.

headline.main: McGreevey's Running Again. Or Maybe He Never Stopped.

docs.abstract: Article discusses James McGreevey's re-election campaign for Mayor of Woodbridge, NJ; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In his new budget request, President Clinton will again ask Congress to open Medicare to people 55 to 64 years old, Administration officials said today. Though the proposal died in Congress last year, Mr. Clinton will resubmit it, in part because he is concerned about the erosion of private insurance coverage among people 55 to 64, the officials said. Medicare now covers people who are 65 and older or who are disabled.

headline.main: Clinton Revives Proposal to Expand Medicare

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton's new budget request will again ask Congress to open Medicare to people 55 to 64 years old; Administration says President is concerned about erosion of private insurance coverage among people in that age group; Medicare now covers people 65 and older or who are disabled; number of people without health insurance rose by 4 percent in 1997, to 43.4 million; number of uninsured people age 55 to 64 rose by 7 percent, to 3.2 million (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For Dr. Clement Barone, a radiologist on the Upper East Side, the final straw came when Blue Cross Blue Shield told him it was cutting reimbursements for mammograms to $42 each. (He charges $200.) He dropped the plan, and said he might stop accepting all managed care soon. Dr. Barney Softness, a pediatrician on West End Avenue, said he decided that he could take no more when Oxford Health Plans suggested that he cut costs by getting rid of the registered nurses in his office. Instead, he told Oxford goodbye.

headline.main: Rebellion in White: Doctors Pulling Out Of H.M.O. Systems

docs.abstract: Growing numbers of doctors in New York, particularly those serving upper-middle-class patients, are dropping out of managed care plans with lowest reimbursement rates or biggest administrative headaches; others are looking for alternative ways to negotiate with HMO's, like forming group practices or other professional associations that have more leverage to seek better reimbursement rates; hospitals are asking New York State Attorney General's office to look into managed-care company practices; there are signs that movement extends past New York City's borders: Summit Medical Group, in Summit, NJ, with 100 doctors, just dropped Blue Cross; Dr Greg Sachs, president of Medical Society of NJ, says he expects more doctors to quit HMO's; patients whose doctors leave managed care plans have option of paying themselves or finding another doctor; some health care experts are predicting that tiered health care system is in offing as result; as long as employers continue to offer plans that give employees chance to go to doctors outside their networks, and HMO's continue to push doctors to cut costs, more are likely to leave HMO's; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: JEFF TUCKER of Waterbury used to have a fairly typical man's perspective on the concept of going to spa for a facial treatment. ''It was a feminine place to go, and that's it,'' he said. But he knew Lisa Grenier, who owns Cara Bella Natural Skin Clinic in Watertown, and she told him about male customers who were warming up to the notion of getting scrubbed and rubbed for relaxation. So, frazzled by stress one day, he decided to give a facial a chance.

headline.main: It's a Guy Thing Now at the Spa

docs.abstract: Connecticut day spas report increasing attendance by men, traditionally relegated to golf courses, race tracks or bar stools because of prevailing gender stereotypes; industry officials say men comprise growing segment of $50 billion-a-year market; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As state legislatures nationwide start new sessions, lawmakers are beginning to debate how to spend their biggest windfall in recent years: tens of billions of dollars from tobacco settlement deals. While some elected officials are calling for the money to be spent on health care efforts and antismoking campaigns, others are urging that it be used on projects unrelated to tobacco, including new schools or jails, and even sidewalk repair. Still other lawmakers say the tobacco windfall should be used to eliminate state debts or be given to taxpayers as rebates.

headline.main: TOBACCO WINDFALL BEGINS TUG-OF-WAR AMONG LAWMAKERS

docs.abstract: State legislators around nation debate how to spend their biggest windfall in recent years: tens of billions of dollars from tobacco settlement deals; some elected officials want money to be spent on health care efforts and antismoking campaigns; others urge money be used on projects unrelated to tobacco, including new schools or jails; others say money should be used to eliminate state debts or be given to taxpayers as rebates; question of how to spend settlement dollars takes on fractured look that reflects financial and political peculiarities of each locality; over next 25 years, all 50 states and some cities will receive almost $246 billion from cigarette producers as result of lawsuits to recover Medicaid money spent treating smoking-related illnesses (M)
